Award.AwardTitle: CRII: CHS: Developing Next-Generation Rapid Prototyping Tools to Catalyze Innovation in Smart Textiles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project works towards rapid prototyping smart textiles by generating the core insights necessary to support broader participation in this unique domain. This research will generate these insights through the design, development, and systematic evaluation of a tool for designing smart textiles. Smart textiles combine age-old processes of knitting and weaving with advances in fiber-based smart materials to create soft and flexible circuits for a wide range of applications. To date, smart textiles have been designed to do things like harvest energy from body movement or integrate the display and sensing capacities of a smartphone on the sleeve of one's shirt. While initial advances in smart textiles reveal their potential to significantly benefit society, the difficulty of prototyping smart textiles is limiting innovation in this nascent but transformational design space.

This research will support innovation in smart textiles and advance the state of the art in computer-aided design and fabrication by synthesizing the workflows of textile and circuit design. Developing the prototyping tool will require the following: (1) developing computational representations of smart textiles; (2) developing and evaluating novel techniques for bridging textile and circuit design, and (3) studying the unique forms of expressivity and engagement that emerge from the tool. In the process, this research will produce a set of generalizable data structures and user interface techniques to support broad audiences in designing and fabricating smart textiles. Additionally, the insights this research will produce on new forms of expression and engagement that emerge from combining computation and craft are necessary to further ubiquitous computing research, which seeks to integrate technology into the rich material landscapes that characterize everyday life. While many will benefit from exploring the applicability of smart textiles in their lives and work, prior research suggests that the practices this research will make possible are likely to resonate with under-represented groups in science and engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant has been successful in its aims to develop computational representations of smart textiles, novel techniques for bridging textile and circuit design, and uncovering unique forms of expressivity and engagement that emerged within practices of smart textile weaving.

The research questions of this grant were addressed through the design and implementation of AdaCAD, and open-source tool for designing woven drafts with integrated circuitry. The tool is publicly available for community contribution via GitHub and as a free web-based user interface for anyone to use. During the design, development, and evaluation of AdaCAD, we discovered that certain weaving techniques, such as double weaving, supplemental warps, and supplemental wefts are used more commonly within weaving projects where one is integrating circuitry. Furthermore, the traditional representation of woven structures, as a grid defining where yarns cross over and under each other, created problems for smart textiles designers because it did not support the designer in easily understanding the paths of the individual yarns (traditional or conductive) within the woven textile. Thus, we designed AdaCAD with specific supports for these commonly used features as well as offering users’ multiple views to view both the geometry and composition of the yarns within a woven draft. Interviews with smart textiles weavers based in art and engineering showed that the features of the tool were particularly exciting, useful, and addressed problems that no other tools addressed. As we have continued to use AdaCAD during collaborative design practices with both artists and engineers, we have created complex color-changing textile patterns, integrated sensors for measuring force using a variety of different stitch techniques, several prototypes for dry-electrodes with different materials and stitches for robust biometric sensing. Additionally, we have created several smart and connected, fully integrated garments, headbands, and tapestries that communicate information directly to a computer system. These creative outcomes have emphasized the critical role “play” and improvisation have in smart textiles weaving, even when using a design tool in advance of production. A designer must continually work on the physical equipment and design equipment in quick iterations. The variability of the yarns, yarn combinations, tensions, stitches, etc. created important differences in the textiles that cannot be adequately simulated by present-day technology. Thus, one approaches our tool, and weaving more broadly, as though they were creating different experiments and tests that they would continually iterate upon, compose with other designs, and adapt to their context. We saw this improvisational aspect as a strength and we conducted several experiments in how our tool could be used in the subsequent modification and repair of textile based circuits, considering the design of textiles to include a longer lifecycle of reusable materials. Additionally, we implemented a series of experiments that directly connect software to the machinery for realtime design and modification on the equipment itself. Our paper describing AdaCAD was awarded a Best Paper Honorable Mention at CHI 2018 and discussed in detail during a keynote talk at the Symposium of Computational Fabrication in 2019. Furthermore, interest in the software has led to connections with businesses developing weaving equipment, local and national handweavers guilds and craft organizations, and we have set up a mailing list to over 200 members of the smart textiles weaving community with whom we communicate about design tools and areas for future innovation. The grant has supported female and non-binary PhD students, as well as several undergraduate students who identify with underrepresented groups in STEM.
